intro: Camellia insularis, commonly known as the island camellia, is a species native to the Ryukyu Islands of Japan. It is a deciduous shrub that typically grows to a height of 1–3 meters, featuring broad, glossy, dark green leaves. The plant produces striking red or pink flowers during the winter months, which are borne on short, hairy pedicels. Camellia insularis prefers well-drained, acidic soil and partial to full sunlight, making it a popular ornamental plant in gardens. Its unique floral display and hardy nature make it a valuable addition to both horticultural and ecological landscapes.
